justification: At baseline, "participants completed several validated questionnaires in the order; Apathy Motivation Index (Ang et al., 2017)…" indicating this instrument was used to assess trait apathy.
The methods list the "Apathy Evaluation Scale (Marin et al., 1991)" among the trait questionnaires administered to measure apathy-related characteristics.
Participants completed the "Five-Factor Model Rating Form (Mullins-Sweatt et al., 2006)" to capture personality traits of conscientiousness and extraversion used in the apathy factor analysis.
The Barratt Impulsivity Scale (Patton et al., 1995) appears in the battery of trait questionnaires, denoting it was the measure of trait impulsivity.
The authors state that participants completed the "Depression-Anxiety-Stress-21 (Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995)" to assess these trait constructs.
To gauge hedonic capacity, the study included the "Snaith-Hamilton Pleasure Scale (Snaith et al., 1995)" among the trait measures.
Trait fatigue was captured with the "Multidimensional Fatigue Inventory (Shahid et al., 2011)" listed in the questionnaire battery.

measured_by: 4-item smartphone EMA motivation scale (derived from Apathy Motivation Index)
justification: "State motivation was the sum score of four motivation items … derived from Apathy Motivation Index … endorsed on a 7-point Likert scale," showing this brief EMA scale operationalised momentary motivation.

measured_by: Single EMA item: 'Right now, I feel happy'
justification: The state assessment included happiness, asked with the item "Right now, I feel happy" rated on a 7-point Likert scale, indicating this item measured momentary happiness.

measured_by: Single EMA item: 'Right now, I feel tired'
justification: Momentary fatigue was assessed through the item "Right now, I feel tired" within the smartphone EMA battery.

measured_by: Single EMA item: 'Last night, I slept well'
justification: Morning prompts included the sleep item "Last night, I slept well", identifying it as the measure of perceived sleep quality.

measured_by: Smartphone reward-effort discounting task (two-alternative forced-choice game)
justification: The authors "developed a smartphone-compatible, gamified reward-effort discounting task … to capture variability in effort-based decision-making," indicating this task measured participants' willingness to expend effort for reward.
construct: Effort-based decision-making / Willingness to exert effort for reward
